citations.narrative:
At the time of inspection, the licensee does not have records of acquisition for three adult female black-tailed prairie dogs,
one adult female domestic pig and one adult male gray squirrel that were added to the inventory since the last inspection.
Records containing the required information for animals disposed of, or acquired for, use in regulated activities (including
those offspring born on premises) are necessary to accurately track animals to ensure their humane care and use. The
licensee must make and maintain records of the inventory, acquisition and disposition of all animals which fully and
correctly disclose the required information.

Facility inventory records include an entry for the flying squirrels that states, "cage left opened 8/13/2023 missing one
flying squirrel - other one caught and exam indicated weakness, thin, lame right front leg - radiographs" When asked
about the incident, the facility representative confirmed the event and stated that both flying squirrels escaped when an
employee did not close the cage; both animals were recovered the same day this was discovered. Radiographs showed
the lame limb was not broken. Both flying squirrels were evaluated by the attending veterinarian (the licensee) and
transported for permanent housing off-site at the licensee's home; they are no longer used for covered activity.
Employment was terminated for the worker responsible for failing to close the cage after servicing it.
Failure to ensure the animals were secure resulted in their escape and the injury of one. The licensee must ensure that all
employees who work with the animals are trained and capable of performing handling tasks as expeditiously and carefully
as possible, to avoid trauma, behavioral stress, harm and discomfort, as well as prevent escapes.
CORRECTED BEFORE THE TIME OF INSPECTION ON AUGUST 29, 2023

There was no documentation for the review of the Contingency Plan within the last year, and no documentation of
employee training over the Contingency Plan.
Timely review of the contingency plan helps ensure that any needed changes are made and communicated to all
personnel that have a role or responsibilities in the plan to help avoid animal discomfort, illness, injury or death in the
event of an emergency or disaster. The licensee must ensure that the contingency plan is reviewed on at least an annual
basis to confirm that it adequately addresses the criteria listed in Section 2.34(a) and must also maintain documentation
of those reviews, to include any amendments or changes made to the plan since the previous year's review. Additionally,
changes must be communicated to applicable personnel within 30 days. Contingency plans, as well as all annual review
documentation and training records, must be made available to APHIS and any funding Federal agency representatives
upon request.
TO BE CORRECTED BY SEPTEMBER 30, 2023

At the time of the inspection, there is one adult male capuchin and three adult female ring-tailed lemurs housed inside the
same room where dogs receive physical therapy on a water treadmill. The dogs receive services as a part of the
veterinary business which is operated on the same premises. Regulated species that are not used for activities regulated
under the Animal Welfare Act (such as care and services provided to veterinary clients) must be housed physically
separate from animals that are used for regulated activities in order to be exempt from Animal Care oversight. If these
animals are co-mingled with animals intended for use in regulated activities such as exhibition, they cannot be guaranteed
exclusion from exhibition since the public may be admitted to the areas where they are housed. In the case of nonhuman
primates that are exhibited, it is also a noncompliance to house them in a way that is not physically separate from any
other business. Failure to house nonhuman primates separately from other businesses can expose them to disease
hazards and stressful housing conditions. It can also hinder the inspection process and the ability to track the movement
of regulated animals. This exhibitor licensee must ensure that housing for nonhuman primates be physically separated
from any other businesses. If a housing facility is located on the same premises as any other businesses, it must be
physically separated from the other businesses. TO BE CORRECTED BY SEPTEMBER 30, 2023

The primary enclosures housing one adult female ring-tailed lemur and one adult male ring-tailed lemur and one adult
male capuchin have rusted areas of metal in several areas, some of which have rusted through to produce holes and
sharp points.
Rusted metal is porous and cannot be easily cleaned and sanitized; rusted-through metal creates sharp points that can
injure the animals. The licensee must ensure that any surfaces that come in contact with non-human primates are free of
excessive rust that prevents the required cleaning and sanitation or that affects the structural strength of the surfaces, and
that all surfaces are free of jagged edges or sharp points.
TO BE CORRECTED BY SEPTEMBER 30, 2023

citations.desc: Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control.
citations.narrative:
Accumulations of mouse droppings are seen in numerous places on the floor throughout the indoor portions of the facility,
including the commissary area and enclosure areas for three adult female and one adult male ring-tailed lemurs and one
adult male capuchin. Three adult mice were seen running through holes in the doors and doorjambs within the
commissary.
Wild rodents can harbor parasites and disease causing microbes that can contaminate food and food prep areas and
cause injury or illness to the animals. The licensee must establish and maintain a safe and effective program for the
control of insects and mammalian pests.
TO BE CORRECTED BY SEPTEMBER 13, 2023

Accumulations of mouse droppings are seen in numerous places on the floor throughout the indoor portions of the facility,
including the commissary area and enclosure areas for two adult female and one adult male South American coati, three
adult female black-tailed prairie dogs, two adult kinkajou, three adult male chinchillas, one adult female gray squirrel, one
adult female ground squirrel and one adult female prehensile tailed porcupine. Several adult and juvenile mice were seen
running through holes in the doors and doorjambs of surrounding areas.
Wild rodents can harbor parasites and disease causing microbes that can contaminate food and food prep areas and
cause injury or illness to the animals. The licensee must establish and maintain a safe and effective program for the
control of insects, ectoparasites, and avian and mammalian pests.
TO BE CORRECTED BY SEPTEMBER 13, 2023

citations.desc: Environment enhancement to promote psychological well-being.
citations.narrative:
At the time of inspection, the facility did not have a documented environmental enhancement plan for avian species.
This plan is required to promote psychological well-being of the avian species at the facility. The facility must develop,
document and follow a species appropriate plan for environmental enhancement adequate to promote the psychological
well-being of birds. The plan must be approved by the attending veterinarian and, at a minimum, must address social
grouping, environmental enrichment, special considerations, restraint, and exemptions to the plan.
TO BE CORRECTED BY SEPTEMBER 30, 2023

citations.desc: Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control.
citations.narrative:
Accumulations of mouse droppings are seen in numerous places on the floor throughout the indoor portions of the facility,
including the commissary area. Several adult and juvenile mice were seen running through holes in the doors and
doorjambs of the commissary and aviary room. Three adult mice were seen running directly into a primary enclosure
housing blue and gold macaws.
A safe and effective program for the control of insects, ectoparasites, and avian and mammalian pests must be
established and maintained so as to promote the health and well-being of the birds and reduce contamination by pests in
animal areas. Insecticides, chemical agents, or other pest control products that may be harmful to the birds must not be
applied to primary enclosures and other bird contact surfaces unless the application is consistent with manufacturer
recommendations or otherwise approved for use and does not harm birds.
TO BE CORRECTED BY SEPTEMBER 13, 2023
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives.
